text:
In today’s video we’re taking you around
Wroclaw.

This was the second stop of our month-long
trip through Poland, and we liked it right
from Day 1.

Our visit to the city was spent wandering
through the University Quarter, cruising down

the Oder River, stumbling into a secret courtyard,
and enjoying a tasty meal or two along the
way.

The following is our travel guide to some
of the best things to do in Wrocław, Poland:
Well good day good day.

But that is not it.
Yeah, so we had to google the pronunciation.
Apparently it is Wroclaw.

So this video is going to be an exercise in
trying to say that name correctly.

The University Quarter (Uniwersytet Wrocławski
/ Universität Breslau) is located in the

north end of the Old Town and it’s worth
visiting even if your days as a student are
over.

Here you’ll find the University of Wroclaw
(Uniwersytet Wrocławski / Universität Breslau),

which is one of the oldest academic institutions
in Central Europe.
The architecture is also stunning!

I mean, could you imagine being a student
here?

So we've got a bit of a womp womp moment going
on right now.
It is literally the story of our lives.

Whenever we got to visit an attraction, a
museum, anything it is closed.

We always go on the day it just happens to
be closed.

And usually we're thinking ahead like it is
probably going to be closed on a Sunday or
a Monday.
But not this time.
On a Wednesday.
Right in the middle of the week.

Anyways, we wanted to visit the Mathematical
Tower.
Yes.
Right behind us and also a very famous classroom.
Right.

With beautiful painted ceilings but we'll
have to come back tomorrow.
There you go.
Tomorrow.

Since we couldn’t visit the interior of
the university, we stopped by the university

church, also known as the Parish of the Most
Holy Name of Jesus (Kościół - Uniwersytecki
p.w.
Najświętszego Imienia Jezus).

Admission is free of charge, though donations
are welcome, and once you’re in, don’t
forget to look up!

Continuing our random wanderings through Wrocław,
we reached the Ossolineum (Zakład Narodowy
im.
Ossolińskich), which quickly piqued our curiosity.

Once a hospital and convent, and later a college,
today it houses one of the largest scientific

libraries in Poland as well as the national
archive.

We visited the courtyard surrounded by mirrored
windows and hydrangeas, and if felt like a
secret garden.
So cool thing about Wroclaw.

They have a whole bunch of little islands
you can visit just north of the University
Quarter.

So we're going to do that next and the plan

Tumski - Dominsel).
We can already see the Cathedral.
We can see the Cathedral.

It was formerly an island that sat between
two branches of the Oder River, and while

that’s no longer the case, it still has
a cathedral, so it partially lives up to its
name.

With much better weather, we then followed
the previous day’s path back to Cathedral
Island.

Along the way, we visited the Silver Arch,
which is a pretty cool sculpture on one of

the smaller islands, and then it was time
for a river cruise.

Well next up we're doing a boat cruise down
the river.

Yeah, and we only paid 20 złoty and that

Yeah, not bad.

You’ll see different boat cruises on offer
just before you cross over to Cathedral Island,

and they depart frequently, so it’s easy
to show up and just get a seat.

Our next stop was Hala Targowa, or Market
Hall.

It’s a nice spot to hit up to get your daily
supply of fresh fruits, deli meats, cheese

and pastries, for a delicious yet affordable
do-it-yourself meal.

So we just walked in and we're going to check

Typical of pretty much every European city

And that’s a wrap for our visit to Wroclaw!

As always, if you have any places to add to
this list or any tips for fellow travellers,
feel free to share those in the comments below.
Until next time and happy travels!
